report_title: Industry Research: Gasket & Seal Manufacturing in the US
executive_summary: Through the end of 2023, gasket and seal manufacturers endured notable hardship, primarily due to the economic contraction brought on by COVID-19. Shutdowns across manufacturing sectors weakened demand for operators' products, in addition to the steep drop in demand for crude oil and natural gas hampering demand from extraction industries. Gasket and seal manufacturers are also highly globalized, so pandemic-related disruptions to supply chains hampered revenue as well. Growth in recent years as downstream industries recover, including an estimated boost of 2.3% in 2023 alone, has not been enough to offset these declines. These trends are expected to cause revenue to fall at a CAGR of 3.9% to an estimated $7.0 billion through the end of 2023.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Economic Volatility During Covid-19 Hampers Manufacturing Output
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Gasket and seal manufacturers are highly dependent on consistent manufacturing output to ensure their products reach a variety of industrial customers. The onset of COVID-19 significantly hampered operators, as manufacturing output fell significantly due to lockdown and social distancing regulations, with global trading conditions severely affected as well. Collapsing new car sales exemplifies this trend, with consumers far less active in discretionary spending and manufacturers enduring significantly lower demand for gaskets and seals.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Spike In Commodity Prices Exacerbates Operational Decline
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: A crucial metric that influences operators' revenue growth is the fluctuation of core input prices, such as rubber, and commodities, such as oil and natural gas, with both having different impacts of revenue in recent years.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Consistent Import Penetration Dampens Domestic Producers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Since seal and gaskets are relatively easy to produce and are not difficult to transport, it creates a lucrative market for foreign competitors and offers domestic operators opportunities to expand their influence globally. Nonetheless, the prevalence of foreign competition ensures domestic manufacturers, who are crucial for seal and gasket operators' success, can procure less expensive goods from abroad to preserve capital.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Economic Recovery Will Accelerate Manufacturing Output From Downstream Manufacturers
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: With stable economic conditions following COVID-19 and recovering global supply chains, seal and gasket manufacturers are poised to enjoy a new wave of manufacturing output and demand from downstream markets. The industrial production index is anticipated to grow, highlighting this trend, with more industrial manufacturers, such as car producers, construction companies and pipeline manufacturers looking to upgrade their products' durability.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Stabilization Of Commodities Will Benefit Operators
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: A positive development for operators is recovering oil and natural gas prices, along with core inputs such as rubber, which will stabilize operators' input costs and ensure consistent demand among pipeline manufacturers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Favorable Global Trade Dynamics Will Bolster Revenue Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: With foreign markets continuing to be a lucrative area of growth, domestic operators will look to expand their customer base beyond domestic operations and take advantage of recovering global supply chains. As the trade-weighted index is poised to slip, more domestic operators will be encouraged to export their goods at a higher rate, creating a more diversified customer base.

industry_definition: Operators primarily manufacture gaskets, packing and sealing devices of all materials, including molded, metallic and nonmetallic materials. Gaskets are mechanical components used to create seals at the point of connection between two pieces of equipment, while packing and seals are usually ring-shaped components that prohibit or limit the leakage of fluid from a device in a pneumatic or hydraulic system.

mixed_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: medium - steady

key_trends: Sharp decline in manufacturing during COVID-19 hampered growth
Volatile commodity prices encourage operators to source input goods from abroad
Continued prevalence of lower-cost foreign competitors encourages operators to import at a higher rate
Full economic recovery will accelerate demand from manufacturers
As commodity prices stabilize, so will operators' production costs

market_segmentation.segment_description: This market segment generates revenue from sales generated among original equipment manufacturers (OEMs), which are primarily composed of automotive and industrial equipment manufacturers. The largest and most consistent market for operators continues to be equipment manufacturers that produce a variety of consumer goods like cars, while also working on industrial projects, such as pipeline manufacturing.

This market segment generates revenue from alternative submarkets that are geared more toward localized uses of gasket and seal products. Most of operators' demand in this segment is also geared toward repair work, particularly as many of the gaskets and seals are far less durable and require regular maintenance to ensure a manufactured product is working properly.

This market segment generates revenue within the maintenance, repair and operations (MRO) market. Many of the gaskets and seals implemented within a manufacturer's product stream will require occasional maintenance and repair work to ensure their product is functioning.

products_and_services.product_description: This product segment generates revenue from the sales of nonmetallic gaskets, also characterized as soft gaskets. Nonmetallic gaskets constitute a significant revenue share for operators, as they are made from various materials like elastomers and flexible graphite, while also servicing low-to-medium pressure applications.

This product segment generates revenue from the sales of molded packing and seals, which are made from rubber or plastic. Molded gaskets create a tighter, more precise seal to minimize outflows, which creates a robust demand niche across multiple manufacturing industries and allows the product to serve a multi-faceted purpose.

This product segment generates revenue from the sales of metallic gaskets, which are fabricated from various metals such as aluminum, copper, steel or brass. Many downstream manufacturing customers have a consistent use for metallic gaskets, with their use being primarily applied toward high pressure and temperature applications due to their robust blow out resistance.

This product segment generates revenue from sales of rotary seals, also characterized as radial shaft seals or lips seals. Rotary seals primarily are implemented within hydraulic pumps and power steering systems to ensure rotary elements are sealed, making them a niche product within car manufacturers.

This product segment generates revenue from sales of axial seals. Axial seals differ from other seals due to their directional application of compression being limited to the top and bottom of an item. Most applications for axial seals focus on usage as secondary seals to assist primary seals preventing the leakage of contaminants, making them an appealing option for many manufacturers.

Two of the smallest product segments generate revenue from sales of compression packing and other seals and gaskets, such as piston rings. Most of these products are made of softer materials, such as elastomers, and are used for easy-to-assemble tasks, as they cannot handle high temperatures and extreme pressure.

Two of the smallest product segments generate revenue from sales of compression packing and other seals and gaskets, such as piston rings. Most of these products are made of softer materials, such as elastomers, and are used for easy-to-assemble tasks, as they cannot handle high temperatures and extreme pressure.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Demand dependent on US industrial output and manufacturing
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Demand for gasket and seal manufacturers is ultimately dependent on US industrial output and manufacturing. Particularly, sales of operators' goods rely heavily automotive component manufacturing, as auto parts producers are a major customer of gaskets and seals.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Reliance on downstream markets like oil/gas and construction
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Operators are also dependent on key downstream markets such as oil and gas exploration and production (E&P) and construction activity, as both of these sectors are major purchasers of operators' products.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Influenced by industrial production, profits and consumer spending
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Operators are highly influenced by fluctuations in industrial production activity, corporate profit and consumer spending.
The industry is also sensitive to industrial activity abroad, as it exports heavily to countries where there is high demand from downstream manufacturing, construction and oil and gas markets.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Rise in US Dollar Bolsters Import Penetration
international_trade_points.trade_description: A stronger US dollar enabled operators to save on purchase costs by acquiring foreign-made input goods like rubber and copper during COVID-19 volatility.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Ease of Production and Transport Boosts Import Trends
international_trade_points.trade_description: Seals and gaskets are light products easier to transport globally. Lower labor costs in import countries like Mexico incentivize operators to source inputs there.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Growth in Free Trade Benefits Exports
international_trade_points.trade_description: Expansion of tariff-free trading like USMCA enhances exports to proximate countries like Canada and Mexico where manufacturing is strong.
As manufacturing grows globally, operators expand internationally to secure production agreements, especially in auto manufacturing hubs like China.

business_locations.location_description: Gasket and seal manufacturers heavily favor areas that have a high saturation of manufacturing companies to ensure proximity to core customers. In states like Illinois, the prevalence of metropolitan centers and a robust manufacturing sector enhances demand, with core customers including automotive and industrial manufacturers.

The Southeast region continues to attract many operators due to its booming industrial facilities and growing consumer population. In states like Florida, growing population centers and a high saturation of automobile component manufacturers ensures establishments have proximity to a variety of customers and can minimize shipping costs.

Although the Southwest lacks the population presence of other regions, it houses a considerable amount of energy companies, such as oil and gas exploration companies. In states like Texas, a booming oil and gas presence ensures gaskets and seals have high demand within this market, enticing many establishments into the region.

The Mid-Atlantic continues to serve as a unique destination for operators due to its proximity to core international markets and as a hotspot for broader international trade. In states like New York, a high saturation of population centers and prominent manufacturing hubs ensure a niche demand for operators in the region.

The Western region continues to be a popular location for establishments due to the prevalence of core manufacturing companies, particularly within the technological sphere. In states like California, booming population areas provides many downstream customers, while proximity to foreign markets ensures maximum exposure for operators.

Some of the other regions with a significantly smaller share of establishments include the New England, the Plains and the Rocky Mountains regions. These areas lack a significant manufacturing presence and have significantly larger distances between clients, creating higher shipping costs for operators.

Some of the other regions with a significantly smaller share of establishments include the New England, the Plains and the Rocky Mountains regions. These areas lack a significant manufacturing presence and have significantly larger distances between clients, creating higher shipping costs for operators.

Some of the other regions with a significantly smaller share of establishments include the New England, the Plains and the Rocky Mountains regions. These areas lack a significant manufacturing presence and have significantly larger distances between clients, creating higher shipping costs for operators.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Operators must comply with FDA regulations regarding gasket materials being generally regarded as safe (GRAS).
Operators follow standards set by the American Society of Mechanical Engineers for production and use of gaskets and seals.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Life Cycle Stage: mature, Industry Assistance Level: low - steady, Technology Change Level: high, Globalization Level: high - increasing, Competition Level: high - increasing
Capital Intensity Level: low, Concentration Level: low, Regulation Level: light - steady
There are very few regulatory barriers for new entrants. Most regulations are enforced by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), with limited oversight from associations.

New operators experience significant start-up costs. A large investment into machinery and facilities to produce seal and gaskets creates a heavy start-up cost for new entrants, particularly as equipment continues to undergo innovation.

There is some differentiation across the industry. Although most revenue continues to be generated via gasket sales, operators sell a variety of products, which creates a variety of demand niches across different sectors.

basis_points.basis_description: Competition between gasket and seal manufacturers occurs primarily based on price. Operators that act as original equipment manufacturers (OEMs) for other manufacturers that demand gaskets and seals operate in highly competitive industries.

Operators seek to maintain and expand their competitiveness through substantial capital investment in research, development, marketing and operations. This strategy is essential to meet the changing technological needs of customers.

Operators contend with external competition from imported gaskets and seals. While imports substitutes are expected to contract slightly as a share of domestic demand during the period, they are estimated to account for a significant 60.7% in 2023.

concentration_points.concentration_title: High Level of Price Competition Limits Market Share Expansion
concentration_points.concentration_description: Gasket and seal manufacturers endure significant price-based competition from smaller competitors and global producers, which creates limited opportunities for growth.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Volatile Economic Conditions Create Uncertain Market Conditions
concentration_points.concentration_description: Broader volatility within the manufacturing sector during COVID-19 created uneven demand from core downstream markets, which encouraged operators to stay small.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Fluctuations in prices of raw materials like rubber, metals and plastics directly influence production costs for gasket and seal manufacturers.
Rising gas and oil prices increased transportation costs across the industry.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Low capital expenditure relative to wages
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: For every $1.00 spent on wages, an estimated $0.05 is spent on capital investment. Manufacturing operations require a highly skilled labor force, with wages accounting for slightly less than one-third of revenue over the past five years.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Depreciation consumes marginal share of revenue
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Depreciation reaches an estimated 1.8% of revenue in 2023, indicating low capital intensity.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Volatility in commodity prices like rubber exacerbates revenue volatility for gasket and seal manufacturers.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Rising technological innovation has improved the effectiveness and ease of manufacturing gaskets and seals.
Operators are increasingly incorporating automation and 3D printing into production processes.

FAQs.question: How is your company affected by rising imports?
FAQs.answer: Rising imports represent a source of external competition for operators. Recently heightened tariffs are expected to make imports less competitive in domestic markets.

FAQs.question: Have exports offered an opportunity for your company?
FAQs.answer: Yes, exports allow companies to serve fast-growing emerging markets. Retaliatory tariffs from import destinations threaten US exports.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Yes, COVID-19 led to a steep decline in many input costs, such as steel and rubber. Following the end of pandemic-related disruptions, these costs increased dramatically, hampering profit. Companies rely on rubber and metal commodities as primary inputs.

FAQs.question: Have you looked into setting up manufacturing facilities in lower-wage regions of the country?
FAQs.answer: Yes, many of the largest players in this industry have operations abroad. Companies are more likely to open factories in Mexico given the country's proximity to the US and participation in the USMCA.

FAQs.question: Do you use SAP software systems to optimize all aspects of your company's manufacturing, sales, inventory and distribution channels?
FAQs.answer: Companies are incentivized to use SAP software to improve the overall efficiency of operating large inventories. Given the variation in operators' products, most companies utilize some sort of inventory management software.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing in technology like 3D printing to establish a competitive edge?
FAQs.answer: Few companies are investing in 3D printing due to its niche use for operators. 3D printing may be used for custom-made gaskets and seals.

FAQs.question: How have international tariffs impacted your ability to import and export products?
FAQs.answer: High tariffs from import-destination countries will hinder the competitiveness of exports. Heightened trade tariffs have the potential to hamper industry revenue growth.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: No, regulatory expenses do not directly impact revenue to a significant degree. Regulation regarding the manufacturing sector is typically aligned with environmental regulations.

FAQs.question: How has input price volatility affected profit margins over the past 12 months?
FAQs.answer: Input price volatility negatively affects profit margins. Companies hedge against volatility using derivatives to lock-in certain commodity prices.

FAQs.question: What ongoing financing challenges does your company face?
FAQs.answer: A rising interest rate environment will make the cost of borrowing more expensive. As the cost of borrowing increases, companies are less likely to make long-term capital investments.

FAQs.question: Does the company provide after-sales advice to its customers? Does the company generate revenue through accessory sales?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers need to provide ongoing support for their machinery to retain customers.

FAQs.question: How do you attract and maintain relationships with suppliers? How can you diversify your connections?
FAQs.answer: A diverse range of suppliers provides manufacturers with the ability to source a wider range of cost-effective inputs.

FAQs.question: Is your company dominant in any particular regional markets? What range does your company have in terms of viable operating area?
FAQs.answer: Operators benefit from being in close proximity to regional hubs of industrial manufacturing activity.

FAQs.question: How is your company affected by the TWI? How is your business affected by imports?
FAQs.answer: An increase in the value of the US dollar, reflected by an increasing TWI, makes domestic goods more expensive relative to imports. This supports import penetration and hurts domestic manufacturers, which include operators in this industry.

FAQs.question: How does the current number of new car sales affect your company? How can you adapt as new car sales decrease?
FAQs.answer: Operators manufacture various types of automotive seals and gaskets such as head gaskets, coaxial seals, oil seals and O-rings. An increase in the number of car sales and the subsequent increase in the production of automobiles leads to greater demand for the industry's products.

FAQs.question: How much of your demand comes from manufacturers? Do you have contracts with a variety of downstream manufacturers?
FAQs.answer: Industrial seals and gaskets are used in a variety of industrial processes and applications. A rising industrial production index translates to increased demand for industry products.
